HighlightText: Irregular and regular forms therefore would be the inevitable outcome of two mental subsystems, words and rules, trying to do the same thing,

Title: Words and Rules
Author: Steven Pinker
HighlightText: Science is not always kind to folklore from the natural world. Elephants do forget, lemmings don’t commit mass suicide, two snowflakes can be alike, we use more than 5 percent of our brains, and Eskimos don’t have a hundred words for snow.

Title: Words and Rules
Author: Steven Pinker
HighlightText: We need to communicate, and language is the fulfillment of that need. For every idea there is a word and vice-versa, and we utter the words in an order that reflects the connections among ideas. If this common-sense view is true, there would be little need to speak of language being a complex system. The complexity would reside in the meanings, and language would reflect that complexity directly.

Title: Words and Rules
Author: Steven Pinker
HighlightText: Language does express meaning as sound, of course, but not in a single step

Title: Words and Rules
Author: Steven Pinker
HighlightText: One is a storehouse of memorized words, the mental lexicon. Another is a team of rules that combine words and parts of words into bigger words, a component called morphology. A third is a team of rules that combine words into phrases and sentences, a component called syntax. The three components pass messages about meaning back and forth with the rest of the mind

Title: Words and Rules
Author: Steven Pinker
HighlightText: semantics

Title: Words and Rules
Author: Steven Pinker
HighlightText: Morphology may be divided into derivation—rules that form a new word out of old w

Title: Words and Rules
Author: Steven Pinker
HighlightText: and inflection—rules that modify a word to fit its role in a sentence

Title: Words and Rules
Author: Steven Pinker
HighlightText: Syncretism—one form, several roles—is one kind of violation of the simplest conceivable system in which every sound has one meaning and vice-versa

Title: Words and Rules
Author: Steven Pinker
HighlightText: why do we need separate boxes for semantics (the thoughts expressed in language) and the lexicon?

Title: Words and Rules
Author: Steven Pinker
HighlightText: First, the English irregular verbs could not have arisen simply from a communal effort to optimize clarity.

Title: Words and Rules
Author: Steven Pinker
HighlightText: Also, irregular forms do not correlate with any kind of meanin

Title: Words and Rules
Author: Steven Pinker
HighlightText: Compared to ordinary verbs they are less filling; a light verb doesn’t have a meaning that stays with it, but takes on dozens of meanings, especially in combination with particles such as in, out, up, off, over, and around

HighlightText: Finally, there are nouns that take Latin or Greek plurals

HighlightText: A fourth class of nouns takes the regular -s ending but changes its final consonant, usually f but sometimes th or s, from unvoiced to voiced

Title: Words and Rules
Author: Steven Pinker
HighlightText: Another three irregular plurals take the old Anglo-Saxon suffix -en rather than -s:

Title: Words and Rules
Author: Steven Pinker
HighlightText: Many nouns ordinarily don’t take any plurals: mass nouns such as mud, celery, furniture, and evidence are treated as seamless stuff rather than countable things.

Title: Words and Rules
Author: Steven Pinker
HighlightText: The perpetrator is a process of language change that is the opposite of the various slurrings and swallowings and cutting of corners that we have seen so far. All of those changes make it easier for the speaker to speak but do nothing for the listener, who would rather have the speaker enunciate clearly

Title: Words and Rules
Author: Steven Pinker
HighlightText: irregular verb in English, the so-called strong verbs. They belong to alliances with similar sounds, and despite this solidarity, they have been dwindling for millennia.

Title: Words and Rules
Author: Steven Pinker
HighlightText: The rules themselves, however, did not survive.

HighlightText: The irregular patterns refuse to die

Title: Words and Rules
Author: Steven Pinker
HighlightText: It’s been three hundred and fifty years since Leviathan, and scholars are still debating rationalism and empiricism. Both sides appeal to theoretical coherence, intuitive plausibility, political ramifications, and harmony with the morals of modern science, but these are pretty squishy criteria, and the debate rages on.

Title: Words and Rules
Author: Steven Pinker
HighlightText: What are the facts to be explained? Irregular verbs defy the suggestion that they are memorized by rote because they show three kinds of patterning.

Title: Words and Rules
Author: Steven Pinker
HighlightText: First, irregular past-tense forms are similar in sound to their base forms.

Title: Words and Rules
Author: Steven Pinker
HighlightText: Second, a few kinds of change from a stem to its past are seen over and over among the 164 irregular verbs.

Title: Words and Rules
Author: Steven Pinker
HighlightText: Third, the verbs undergoing a given irregular change are far more similar than they have to be.

Title: Words and Rules
Author: Steven Pinker
HighlightText: Noam Chomsky and Morris Halle’s 1968 magnum opus The Sound Pattern of English

Title: Words and Rules
Author: Steven Pinker
HighlightText: Another rein on rules keeps each one in a stratum (a component or subcomponent) so that it does not run wild and apply where it shouldn’t.

Title: Words and Rules
Author: Steven Pinker
HighlightText: This economy and power also accrues to rules that fiddle with vowels if the vowels are dissolved into features

Title: Words and Rules
Author: Steven Pinker
HighlightText: the Great Vowel Shift in the fifteenth century

Title: Words and Rules
Author: Steven Pinker
HighlightText: Chomsky and Halle therefore proposed that English has a rule of Long Vowel Tensing, which tenses all long vowels, and a rule of Diphthongization, which adds the little ys and ws that give us the two-part vowels in lake (leh-eek), glide (gla-eed), need (nee-y’d), loud (la-ood), and road (ro-ood).

Title: Words and Rules
Author: Steven Pinker
HighlightText: English spelling is not only exonerated of the charge that it is an illogical, sadistic mess, but “comes remarkably close to being an optimal orthographic system.”

Title: Words and Rules
Author: Steven Pinker
HighlightText: The defunct-rule explanation has an advantage over the Chomsky-Halle-Mohanan theory.

Title: Words and Rules
Author: Steven Pinker
HighlightText: First, why would the child bother if the rules are there only to generate the surface form, and the child already has the surface form?

Title: Words and Rules
Author: Steven Pinker
HighlightText: Chomsky-Halle-Mohanan theory cannot explain the third kind of similarity running through the irregulars: the similarities among stems, as in sting, string, sling, stink, sink, swing, and spring.

Title: Words and Rules
Author: Steven Pinker
HighlightText: irregular clusters are family resemblance categories

Title: Words and Rules
Author: Steven Pinker
HighlightText: They don’t have strict, all-or-none definitions that specify which verbs are in and which verbs are out. Instead they have fuzzy boundaries and members that are in or out to various degrees depending on how many properties they share with one anothe

Title: Words and Rules
Author: Steven Pinker
HighlightText: morphology box—sitting between meaning and sound

Title: Words and Rules
Author: Steven Pinker
HighlightText: The mainspring of the model, then, is forming associations between features and features, and that duplicates the human habit that embarrassed the words-and-rules theory: generalizing irregular patterns to similar words.

Title: Words and Rules
Author: Steven Pinker
HighlightText: First, Rumelhart and McClelland’s pattern associator memory is a device that only produces past-tense forms

Title: Words and Rules
Author: Steven Pinker
HighlightText: Second, the model computes every detail of the pronunciation of the past-tense form. Yet we saw that many of these details, such as the choice among -t, -d, and id, are found in fifteen different parts of the language system

Title: Words and Rules
Author: Steven Pinker
HighlightText: Third, by forgoing the use of lexical entries and relying entirely on a word’s sound to compute its past-tense form, the model cannot tell the difference between two words that have the same sound.

Title: Words and Rules
Author: Steven Pinker
HighlightText: A fourth problem is that Rumelhart and McClelland had to use some jiggery-pokery to get the model to duplicate children’s stages of language development.

Title: Words and Rules
Author: Steven Pinker
HighlightText: One phenomenon, two models, both explaining too much to be completely wrong, both too flawed to be completely right. Prince and I have proposed a hybrid in which Chomsky and Halle are basically right about regular inflection and Rumelhart and McClelland are basically right about irregular inflection.
